title: upgrade insert-module-globals for newline fix
body: This prevents parse errors by pulling in fixes from @jwalton to address sources that don't end in newlines, like those from `coffeeify`, which include module globals. Tests continue to pass.

The file is there but I'm not sure why it can't find it. This is after I made the bundle.js, in my client.

title: preserve require order from the source
Respect ordering of stream entries
body:
Added streams (`require(stream, {entry: true})`) are not appended to
the internal `_entries` array like their resolved path conterparts.
_entries is used to determine entry indexing in the ouput bundle.
This commit makes sure entry streams are executed in order in the
ouput bundle.

title: Including only first level dependency in a bundle
body:
Is it possible ? I could use the exclude / externalise flag but there are just too many dependency it is not practical. 
The purpose of this is to have a separate bundle includes only the tests and let browserify find the missing dependencies in a the main app bundle.

./buffer_ieee754 not found...

It looks like one of browserify's internal dependencies is buffer_ieee754, although I'm not sure which is the chicken and which is the egg in this case. I've crafted a simple test case in gist (https://gist.github.com/bscottm/8906034); merely require-ing elasticsearch.jquery.js is enough to trigger the bug.

elasticsearch.jquery.js is browserified source, which should already be self contained.

Is this a bug or am I misusing browserify?

title: The default output from CLI is different than using the API...
body:
``` bash
$ browserify test.js -o test-browserified.js
```

And

``` javascript
var b = browserify();
b.add( "test.js" );
var readable = b.bundle();
...
```

Both outputs are ok, but in one case the dependency code is on top of the main code of the module, and in the other it's the opposite.

I have checked for version inconsistency - both the globally installed tool and the module I use in my code are "3.24.13".

title: Issue creating 2 bundles in sequence...
When will browserify be done? [v4 discussion]
body:
I think browserify has been going pretty well at achieving the goal of making npm modules viable in the browser, but what would it look like for browserify to be "done"? Not "done" in terms of "dead", but "done" in terms of the vision is clearly defined and settled, with only patches and dependency upgrades necessary, with other depended-upon  modules taking up the bulk of the experimental work. I want browserify to become a boring tool that hardly ever changes like sed or awk that you can just take for granted.

Here are some hurdles to being "done":
- es6 modules. These already somewhat work with userland transforms and can be turned into a default global transform once a stable version of node ships with es6 modules, perhaps slightly before. However, es6 modules have all kinds of fancy new runtime loading mechanisms that we will need to hack around and ignore to make everything play nicely together.
- addressing the use-cases for multiple bundles and different kinds of output
- feature additions to modules in node core

For v4 I want to heavily start pushing for module authors to depend on explicit npm versions of modules instead of whatever gets bundled in with the core shims, echoing what @rvagg says in [this blog post about readable-stream](http://www.nearform.com/nodecrunch/dont-use-nodes-core-stream-module). Explicit versioning will go a long ways toward future-proofing modules so that we can depend on them and they will just work, even far in the future when node may have changed out from under these modules. Part of making this easy will be working with module authors to get approximate 1:1 parity with node core module names like `path` published to npm so that module authors can `require('path/')` and put path in their package.json with explicit versioning.

A new command, `browserify --warn` will be introduced to point out where implicit globals and core modules are being depended on instead of explicit versions.

The support for multiple bundle output in will also be improved in v4. Much of that work has already been done in [factor-bundle](https://github.com/substack/factor-bundle); it's just a matter of deciding whether to bring this use-case properly into core or to integrate this into a [new plugin system](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/620) that has been proposed.

For v4 I'm punting on es6 modules for now because there aren't enough concrete manifestations of them for it to be a problem for browserify yet. However all of browserify's AST machinery should [now work with es6 syntax](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/614).

title: Fix typo in link to commondir in README
Unexpected string
module.id is undefined and causing ZeroClipboard to break
body: It seems current browserify leaves `module.id` undefined in a browserified module. I determined this just by `console.log(module.id)` in the browser. Digging around a bit it looks like maybe earlier browserify versions had this. In any case, missing `module.id` causes issues with trying to install zeroclipboard through npm, bundle it with browserify, and run it in a browser. See [zeroclipboard issue 332](https://github.com/zeroclipboard/zeroclipboard/issues/332) for reference.

body: The copyright year was out of date (2008). Copyright notices must list the current year. This commit updates the listed year to 2014.

title: Support require fallback for strange environments
body:
See: https://twitter.com/rwaldron/status/430414189413138433

Basically: there is a need to allow non-browserifieds modules to defer to another `require` function. In this example @rwaldron wanted to use `node-serialport` from `node-webkit`'s require inside of a `browserify` bundle.

Solution: --require-fallback $name

Make a CLI option to fallback to an environment's require function if we did not bundle that file.

title: Why is the prelude obfuscated in Browserify output?
body:
Browserify output starts with this:

``` javascript
(function e(t,n,r){function s(o,u){if(!n[o]){if(!t[o]){var a=typeof require==
"function"&&require;if(!u&&a)return a(o,!0);if(i)return i(o,!0);throw new 
Error("Cannot find module '"+o+"'")}var f=n[o]={exports:{}};t[o][0].call(
f.exports,function(e){var n=t[o][1][e];return s(n?n:e)},f,f.exports,e,t,n,r)}
return n[o].exports}var i=typeof require=="function"&&require;for(var o=0;o<
r.length;o++)s(r[o]);return s})({1:[function(require,module,exports){
'use strict';
```

Since the inlined modules themselves are unminified, I still need to run the whole bundle through a minifier for production anyway.

So... why obfuscate the prelude like this? Why not print it out with proper formatting and variable names, so curious devs can better understand how a Browserify bundle works?

title: [RFC] Plugins
body:
I'd like to propose a new feature for browserify called _Plugins_.
## What is a plugin?

Plugins are pieces of code which provide browserify with new functionality.

Plugins:
- have access to browserify configuration API — `.transform()`, `.require()` calls — and can configure browserify in some logically complete and sound way
- have access to browserify bundler lifecycle (browserify might introduce some kind of a plugin API for that)
## Motivation

The motivation for this is to provide browserify with more flexible command line API which would enable more use cases and at the same time remove unneeded complexity from browserify core.
### Example: implement `--standalone` functionality as a plugin

Currently, `--standalone` functionality belongs to core, but with enough hooks from browserify we can move it out of the core into a separate package, which then would be used by browserify in a way like:

```
% browserify --plugin standalone --standalone-name Project.Library ...
```

See below for a dicussion on using plugins from a command line.
### Example: implement stylesheet bundler as a plugin

One can implement a plugin for browserify which bundles all references stylesheets in a separate CSS bundle. The usage would be like:

```
% browserify \
    --plugin css-bundle --css-bundle-out ./bundle.css \
    -o ./bundle.js ./index.js
```

The gist of the implementation of such bundler:
- plugin installs source transform which collects modules with CSS source into an array and replaces module contents with a stub
- on "bundle-end" lifecycle hook plugin writes contents of the array into output stream for a CSS bundle (filename passed via `out` option).
### Example: use watchify as a plugin

Watchify can be used from a command line as a plugin:

```
browserify --plugin watchify -o ./bundle.js ./index.js
```
## Plugin definition

Plugin is a module which exports a function to configure `Browserify` object. Function takes two arguments:
- `browserify` is a `Browserify` instance
- `opts` (optional) is an object with plugin options

```
module.exports = function(b, opts) {
  // needed configuration
}
```

Notes:
- Plugins have access to browserify arguments via `b.argv`.
## Command line usage

I propose adding `-p/--plugin` flag which would enable loading plugins from Node modules:

```
% browserify --plugin standalone ...
% browserify -p standalone ...
```

This will load `standalone` package and use its value as a plugin.

To specify options for a plugin one should use command line options which are prefixed by plugin's package name:

```
% browserify --plugin standalone --standalone-name MyLibrary ...
```

That way plugin `umd` will be called with `{name: "MyLibrary"}` object as the `options` argument.

Notes:
- How we can pass options to plugin if we are loading it not from a package but from a module inside package or from a local module? We can replace `[\./]` with a `-` in a module name. For example, `--mod-plugin-name x` would specify `name` option for plugin which loaded from `./mod/plugin` .
- How to handle boolean command line options?
## API usage

There's no API level changes for browserify needed, you just need to call plugins directly from your code with needed options:

```
var browserify = require('browserify');
var standalone = require('standalone');
var anotherPlugin = require('anotherPlugin');

var b = browserify();
standalone(b, {...});
anotherPlugin(b, {...});
```

Alternatively we can add `Browserify.plugin()` configuration method which would provide some sugar for the code above:

```
Browserify.prototype.plugin = function(p, opts) {
  // resolve p is p is a String
  p(this, opts);
  return this
}
```
## Possible addition for browserify API
- Implement "start bundle" hook — plugin can initialize some state based on `options` passed to the `bundle()` call.
- Implement "end bundle" hook — plugin can override resulted bundle and cleanup its state if needed
- ... more hooks?

Hooks like "start bundle" and "end bundle" might be not necessary cause plugins can just 
monkey patch browserify instance with a newer `bundle()` implementation which wraps a previous one.

title: Generate UMD modules without deps?
body:
Is it possible to generate UMD modules without the dependencies bundled and without having to list out every dependency to exclude?

My use case is that I have a multi-module library. Some of the modules in the library require others. I'd like to create UMD versions of each module (but not make them standalone) so that end users can use RequireJS, etc, and only require the modules they need to use.

In other words, I'm looking for a 1:1 conversion of node/CommonJS modules to UMD modules.

Thanks!

title: V3.24.3 breaks strict mode
body:
Updating from v3.24.2 to v3.24.3 results in the following error when bundling code with `"strict mode"` turned on.
`Line 1: Strict mode function may not have duplicate parameter names]
`
From a cursory glance at the generated output it seems the following builtin function in the browserify preamble is responsible for the error:
`(function (process,global,Buffer,__argument,__argument,__argument,__argument,__filename,__dirname){...

`

title: global modules with debug source maps
body:
Hello, 

I'm trying to run a script from webstorm to build the bundle with debug source maps and one of the modules public.  I used to only run the first line below to generate the source maps and it worked fine. However, now that I need a global module, I'm a bit stumped. Any help is appreciated
# !/bin/sh

browserify --entry main.js --outfile bundle.js --debug
browserify -r ./setup.js > bundle.js

title: Error: Line 2: Unexpected token :
body:
When building a bundle with:

```
browserify test.json > build.js
```

browserify throws an error since upgrading to version 3.24.3 and above.

browserify@3.24.2 -> OK
browserify@3.24.3 -> Error: Line 2: Unexpected token :
browserify@3.24.8 -> Error: Line 2: Unexpected token :

test.json

```
{
    "global": "foo"
}
```

The string "global" seems to be the problem.

title: getId in .pack() returns a very strange ID for "external" files, causing the bundle to be unuseable
body:
If you provide an "external" file, like so:

``` bash
browserify --transform hbsfy --external ./client/app/index.js --entry test/client/index.js --outfile build/tests.js
```

Browserify will try and assign an ID during packing, here: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L458

The problem is, this external file has an "undefined" index, and on that line, the `deps[key]` ends up being `3Yj3+X`, instead of a numeric index like all the other files are.

Then, when this output file is used, you get the error:

``` bash
Error: Cannot find module '3Yj3+X'
```

I'm not sure what the correct behavior is here, or how to get around this issue. The compiled output file ends up having entries like this in it:

``` javascript
{"../../external/moment":158,"../index":"3Yj3+X","../models/resource":45}
```

Which I can only assume is unintended.

Any idea how to get around this, or how to fix it?

title: add files to bundle while in transform
body:
I am writing a transform add-on which allows using swig templates (with inheritance, imports, ...) in browserify. My current problem ist that for example in: ``` {% extends '../parent.html' %} {% block content %}

Hello World

{% endblock %} ``` We have the file "../parent.html" which is not included into the bundle. So when overwriting the template resolver of swig I am getting an error. I now created an implementation which parses through the templates and finds the paths so they can be added to the bundle (a bit like node-required just for swig). Unfortunately I see no way of adding the gained paths to the bundle. I tried directly calling `bundle.require` but then I got a trace (too much event listeners...). [Here](https://github.com/bodokaiser/node-swigify) is the code so far.

title: Unexpected string
body:
Get this error with `browserify-middleware` and `grunt-browserify`, so I'm assuming it's possibly an issue with `browserify` or `browserify-shim`, for which I've already created an [issue](https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim/issues/27).

``` javascript
SyntaxError: Unexpected string
    at Object.parse (native)
    at /Users/me/project/node_modules/browserify-middleware/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:313:34
    at fs.js:266:14
    at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:107:15)
```

Using version **3.24.2**. Here's a [gist](https://gist.github.com/knownasilya/8676570) of the related files.

title: Option to rename modules in bundled output?
body:
I'd be interested in seeing an option, `--rename-modules`, which would rename all your modules (and rewrite the respective `require` calls) using a simple incrementing naming system – `'1'`, `'2'`, etc.

This way, the bundled output would not contain any module paths, which might be good for security (for organizations concerned about exposing details of their local file system) and it would also save a few bytes.

title: Emit close event on bundle stream with standalone
body:
Currently `watchify` does not work with `standalone` option because the bundle stream does not emit `close` event.

When `this.queue(null)` is called `through` emits `end` event but because the stream is also writable it does not get destroyed. Other way to fix it would be to set  `output.writable = false`.

The test got a bit hacky because when `bundle()` is called before `_ready` event the bug does not appear because it gets wrapped into another `through` stream.

title: Handling inverted dependency trees?
Allow to have dots on names and namespaces
body:
According to http://wiki.commonjs.org/wiki/Packages/1.0, dots are allowed to be used on CommonJS packages names. This change use slashes (that's a not allowed character) to be used as namespaces separator and restored the previous behaviour by just removing the dots. An alternative, more compliant option would be to allow to use them in the namespaces names, but this would require to access to them using brackets instead of object notation.

A proposal for UMD is available as a pull request at https://github.com/ForbesLindesay/umd/pull/13

title: Transforms not applied to named dependencies?
body: I am using [partialify](https://github.com/bclinkinbeard/partialify) as a transform to allow me to `require()` HTML files. It works fine as long as the `require('./some.html')` call is in a file that is `require()'ed via file path, but if it's required by name the HTML gets parsed directly and throws an error. Guessing it's the same root issue as #600.

Is there any other way than having two modules for that?

Are there still plans to expand the options for sourcemaps?

Is there anyway right now I could have relative paths to my sources? Right now the path is localhost/(full-path-to-file) I could make a symlink, but that seems like a waste.

title: adding browserify tools wiki link
body:
- all tools that were there are now in that wiki, so I removed them from that section
- fixed list of transforms wiki link (relative links not working: https://github.com/github/markup/issues/84)

title: adding extract source map example and exorcist link
Calling `deps()` fails to apply transforms
body:
```
fs = require 'fs'
browserify = require 'browserify'
b = browserify({extensions: ['.coffee']})
b.add './assets/browserify/reporting/reporting.coffee'
b.transform require 'coffeeify'

deps = fs.createWriteStream './reporting.js.deps'
b.deps({}).pipe deps
```

This will fail with:

```
Error: Parsing file /Users/jwalton/benbria/loop/assets/browserify/reporting/reporting.coffee: Line 1: Unexpected token ILLEGAL
  at parseDeps (/Users/jwalton/benbria/loop/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:242:45)
  at done (/Users/jwalton/benbria/loop/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:221:13)
  at applyTransforms (/Users/jwalton/benbria/loop/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:197:41)
  at module.exports.trx (/Users/jwalton/benbria/loop/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/index.js:169:17)
  at fs.readFile (fs.js:176:14)
  at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:297:15)
```

At a glance, it looks like module-deps is failing to run any transforms.  Looking with a debugger, I see that [here](https://github.com/substack/module-deps/blob/master/index.js#L196), `transf.length` is 0, as is `trx.length`, so when we get to `parseDeps()`, the `src` is still coffee-script.

It sounds like [this has been broken for a while](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17881692/get-coffee-script-dependency-tree-with-browserify).

title: Add Jisonify to the list of source transforms
body:
I created [Jisonify](https://github.com/schmich/jisonify) to enable the inclusion of [Jison](https://github.com/zaach/jison) parsers in Browserify projects. I thought it should be included in the README list.

Regards,
Chris

title: (#568) - use derequire to rename requires when standalone option is used
body: originally was going to try to fix upstream in [umd](https://github.com/ForbesLindesay/umd/pull/11), but browserify wouldn't have picked up that change. It only does its stuff when the standalone option is used.

title: Multiple implementations of Buffer are bundled
body:
buffer-browserify and insert-module-globals both include an implementation of Buffer

when insertGlobals is true, insert-module-globals inserts it's Buffer into buffer-browserify, causing buffer-browserify's assert to not get loaded and thus crash

title: Reference underscore or lodash
Dublicate prepend "module.exports=" for json files if cache provided
body:
Step to reproduce 
1. browserify and write all deps to cache
2. browserify again with cache (in this step 'module.exports=' prepended to row.source and row goes to cache)
3. browserify again with cache (in this step 'module.exports=' prepended, and result will be 'modules.exports=module.exports=<json>')

May be do check for .json files if they already exists 'module.exports=' at the beginning  of file before prepending 'module.exports' ?

title: Using option `standalone` with streaming input throws an error
browserify doesn't look at NODE_PATH environment variable?
body:
Is it true that browserify currently doesn't take into account the NODE_PATH environment variable when trying to resolve paths? If so, is there a reason for it, or would a pull request implementing it be welcome?

I have tried examples where nodejs can resolve a path based on $NODE_PATH but browserify seemingly cannot. I can give more details if it sounds like this is actually a bug.

title: npm install -g browserify does fail on a clean Node install in Windows

Ending of npm-debug.log is :

```
7848 verbose readDependencies using package.json deps
7849 verbose linkBins combine-source-map@0.3.0
7850 verbose linkMans combine-source-map@0.3.0

title: Guides on authoring transformers
body:
I haven't find any guide on how to create a `transform`er for Browserify. Can anyone guide me through the basics?

Thanks.

title: Require text files (html).
allow to specify global-transform in package.json of root project
body:
I would like to specify `global-transform` not only on the command line, but also inside the `package.json` of the root project that I'm browserifying.

This way browserify will pick them up if run via tools like testling, zuul and beefy.

Here is a `package.json` example:

``` json
{
  "browserify": {
     "transform": [ "local  transform" ],
     "global-transform": [ "global1", "global2" ]
  }
}
```

The idea is that the `global-transform` field will be **ignored for all packges but the root package**.
However if found inside the root package they'd be added to the browserify transforms via; `b.transform(x, { global: true })`.

I''m willing to do a PR for this, but wanted to hash out the details first.

I see  a `_resolve` function that resolves a `package.json`, but as far as I can tell it is only used in `browser-resolve`, but not by top level browserify.
Could we use that same function to try to resolve the root package for the given entry?

As an alternative we could use [find-parent-dir](https://github.com/thlorenz/find-parent-dir) to find the root package instead of using `_resolve`.

title: add 'readable-stream' builtin
body:
I'm using, and also advocating, the use of `require('readable-stream')` and avoiding `require('stream')` completely because of the instability across Node versions compared to the stability of being able to pin to a specific version of readable-stream. For instance Streams3 in 0.11 introduces yet more edge cases that pop up when you're looking for `require('stream')` by default. User-land modules FTW; I just need to get readable-stream updated regularly on schedule with stable and unstable Node releases.

This PR makes `'readable-stream'` a synonym for `'stream'` so that browserify uses stream-browserify instead of readable-stream in all cases. This covers `require('readable-stream').Readable` and `require('readable-stream/readable')` variants.

Tests verify that both require variants actually work, that a `Readable` implementation actually works properly and that readable-stream is never included in a built but stream-browserify is.

title: require declaration syntax / closure compiler
Mootools in Browserify bundle along with regular modules : how ?
body:
I wish to use Browserify for a big project, and it unfortunately involves including the Mootools (v1.4) framework for backward compatibility for the current time being (will be dropped eventually next year, but for now there is too much code depending on it to drop it).

The problem with Mootools, is that it is modular (with a proprietary packaging) but the final build exports a large number of globals (Class, Element, Request, Browser, Mootools, etc for each major class), but also extends the prototypes of many native Javascript entities like Number, String, Array, HTMLElement, and so on.

The point is, it needs to be executed in the global context to work (unfortunately).

I do not absolutely wish to use require('mootools') when I need it, it's fine for me if it's just included in the bundle as the first JS file, and just executed in global context.

Then, other code should be bundled as regular modules.

How could this be done with Browserify, if it could ?

Thanks

title: Module need to be installed by node when "browser" is found in package.json
body:
Hello.

I am creating a backbone application and i'm using Bower.

For some unknown reason, Bower, when install Backbone, pulls too the package.json of his package. In that way, when i `require()` Backbone manually, Browserify reads the package.json and, instead of use the `browser` field in the main folder of my package, it simply ignores it and searches underscore in `package.json` of Backbone.

That behavior can be okay, but, when i simply install `underscore` as a node module in my package, the Browserify not loads it and simply uses the file that i specified in `browser` field in my package.json.

I think that is a issue, that can be temporarily fixed installing underscore as a node module even that i not use it in NodeJS (i am creating a Python project), and have a unexpected behavior (if found in browser field of a `package.json` in a top level directory, why insist in load of a node module?).

That's it, good luck and sorry for the poor english. 

Thanks.

title: Multi page example ?
body:
Hello,

I love Browserify and it would be great if there was even a simple example of how to use it for multi page legacy websites, along the lines of https://github.com/requirejs/example-multipage

---

How to set up a multi-page browserify-based project that has the following goals:
- Each page uses a mix of common and page-specific modules.
- All pages share the same browserify config.
- After an optimization build, the common items should be in a shared common layer, and the page-specific modules should be in a page-specific layer.
- The HTML page should not have to be changed after doing the build.
- The budles have external sourcemap files associated

---

Thanks a lot !

title: Latest browserify raises exception
body:
I was just working on this quick unit test for browserify-transform-tools:

```
it "should gracefully handle a syntax error from browserify", (done) ->
    transform = transformTools.makeRequireTransform "requireTransform", (args, opts, cb) ->
        cb()

    syntaxErrorJs = path.resolve __dirname, "../testFixtures/testWithConfig/syntaxError.js"

    builder = browserify({})
    builder.transform transform
    builder.on 'error', ->
        done()

    builder.add syntaxErrorJs
    builder.bundle (err) ->
        console.log "Got err", err
        done()
```

This runs fine in browserify 3.14.1, but with 3.17.0 I get:

```

- Works in IE6-8 now! (for real this time!)
- Bundle size reduced by 40%! (down to 37KB from 60KB)
- Firefox performance significantly improved (many orders of magnitude) by removing Proxy implementation

More info: https://github.com/feross/native-buffer-browserify/issues/7

I've seen a lot of errors related to libraries attempting to do static analysis on code that has already been analyzed, #525 is related to that, as is proj4js/proj4js#76. It might make sense to rename require calls (that are handled by broserify) to some other name to prevent accidental reanalysis latter. 

I can do a pull if what I'm saying makes sense, unless this would make more sense as a transform.

title: allow to specify global-transforms
do not hide EMFILE error
body: I just finished debugging a very weird case where I ran out of fds and browserify reported that some module simply cannot be found. I changed that behaviour by propagating `EMFILE` up to the user.

title: new require('foo') doesn't resolve `foo`
body:
Given the following JS file:

``` js
new require('data.persistent')
```

And the following Browserify command:

``` sh
$ npm install data.persistent
$ $(npm bin)/browserify -e input.js > output.js
```

The `output.js` file is compiled without resolving and bundling the `require` dependency. Wrapping the require call in parenthesis, however, works:

``` js
new (require('data.persistent')) // resolves the stuff
```

Browserify version is the latest in NPM: `3.14.0`

title: .json extension is mandatory, unlike in node
body:
If you are in browserify's package directory, and make the following file:

``` js
// temp.js
require('./package')
```

And call:

```
$ bin/cmd.js temp.js
Error: Cannot find module './package' from '/Users/drewp/non-spotify/node-browserify'
```

If you add a `.json` to the require it works. The readme mentions this is supposed to work, but apparently something isn't getting resolved properly.

title: Fixes --ignore-missing flag
body: The --ignore-missing flag was having no effect. This fixes it.

title: Issue with HTML pages
Add support for basedir option passed to insert-module-globals
body: I was trying to influence the outgoing filename by setting basedir in the bundle options, but that wasn't working because the option isn't passed to insertGlobals. This PR just adds that option to the insertGlobals call.

title: Add a History.md or Changelog.md
body: It's hard to tell what's changing release to release. At the very least, I would have expected to see a list of breaking changes in 3.0.0... am I missing something?

title: Allow to replace or decorate the call to browser-resolve
